coredata.dc:title: Magnetic field dependence of intramolecular exciplex formation in polymethyelene-linked A–D systems
coredata.dc:creator: Staerk, H.
Kühnle, W.
Treichel, R.
Weller, A.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
An extremely large increase of exciplex fluorescence intensity has been observed with photoexcited compounds pyrene-(CH2) n - DMA in acetonitrile when an external magnetic field of several hundred gauss is applied. The effect is readily explained as originating from the radical ion pair which can undergo a magnetic-field-dependent singlet-triplet conversion due to nuclear hyperfine coupling, or an association to form the exciplex. The increasing influence of the exchange interaction in the radical ion pair with decreasing chain length (CH2) n is evident.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 118, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 12 July 1985 MAGNETIC FIELD DEPENDENCE OF INTRAMOLECULAR EXCIPLEX FORMATION IN POLYMETHYLENE-LINKED A-D SYSTEMS H. STAERK, W. K HNLE, R- TREICHEL and A WELLER Max - Planck-Institut f iir BiophysikalLsche Chemie, Ableitung Spektroskopie, D-3400 Gotlingen, Federal Republic of Germany Received 3 May 1985 An extremely large increase of exciplex fluorescence intensily has been observed with pholoexcitcd compounds pyrene-CCH^n-DMA in acetonilrile when an external magnetic Held of several hundred gauss is applied. "The effect is readily explained as originating from the radical ion pair which can undergo a magnetic-field-dependent singlet-triplet conversion due lo nuclear hyperfine coupling, or an association to form the exciplex. The increasing influence of the exchange mieraclion in the radical ion pair with decrcasmg chain length (CH^),, is evident- L Introduction Ten years ago magnetic field experiments showed that the hyperfine interaction mechanism is responsi- ble for the magnetic-field-dependent fast singlet trip- let conversion m radical ion pairs of electron acceptor/ donor systems (A/D systems) like pyrene/N,N-diethyl- aniline in polar solvents [1]. These experiments were repeated by other workers and the results confirmed [2]. Much theoretical and experimental work has followed since, contributing to the understanding of the magnetic field effect ofthehyperfinetype [3 11]. In detail, the mechanism by which singlet (S) and triplet (T) radical pairs can interconvert is in analogy to the radical pair model of chemically induced dynamic nuclear polarization (CIDNP). According to this theory, nuclear magnetic moments which are coupled to the unpaired electrons by hyperfine inter- action can alter the rate at which the electron spins lose their phase coherence, i.e. undergo S T (or T S) conversion- In the presence of an applied magnetic field greater "than the hyperfine coupling energy (AEf^), the components of the triplet surface split, due to Zeeman interaction, into T^, TQ and T_ levels and the degeneracy of T+, T_ and S is removed. The effect of a stronger external magnetic field then is to inhibit spin conversion of part of the geminate singlet radical pairs from the "ensemble which could at zero 0 009-2614/85/S 03.30 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) field convert to T. For such a radical ion pair, the singlet triplet mixing efficiency induced by hyperfine coupling is determined by the effective coupling con- stant in each radical, 5, = ['Z^a^I^(I^ + 1)] l/2, where a^ is the isotropic hyperfine coupling constant, 1^ the nuclear spin. The^^rt value, the magnetic field strength at which the magnetic field effect has reached half its saturation value, is well correlated with the B, values of the individual radical ions in the unlinked pair [6]. Hyperfine interaction can couple the singlet and the triplet states only if it is greater than the spin ex- change interaction which splits the singlet, S, and the triplet levels, T+, TQ, T_, of the radical pair by an amount 1J. In order to obtain information about the effect of the exchange interaction on the hyperfine- coupling-induced motion of the electron spins m the pair, polympthylene-l iked A D systems, A (CH^) D in polar solvents, have been studied [7,8,10,12] In such systems the radical ions are kept in proximity to each other, so that the probability of a re-encounter is high. After excitation of the acceptor, electron 'transfer from the donor D to the acceptor 1A*' generates the radical ion pair in its overall singlet spin state [9]. Intramolecular back electron-transfer leads either to the ground state with the rate constant A: or, according to the general reaction scheme 19 Volume 118, number l CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 12 July 1985 A-a(fl) , ^^--(CH^-W) - 3(2A--(CH2) -2D+) " rt (1) to the molecular triplet state. The spin multiplicity change in the first step of eq. (1) and its magnetic field dependence can be treated in a fashion similar to that applied to freely diffusing radical pairs [1 9]- The major differences arc the presence of the spin ex- change interaction which leads to a sizeable singlet- triplet splitting and the absence of irreversible diffusive separation of the centers carrying the unpaired elec- trons [7,8,10]. In studies of polymethylene-linked A D systems the magnetic field dependence of the triplet generation of the A moiety, which is one of the recombination products, had been used to monitor the magnetic field effect. Drastic increases of the characteristic B^i^ values with decreasing chain length, n, have been observed [8,10]. For many years it has not been questioned whether the exciplex fluorescence observed in electron transfer fluorescence quenching experiments on A/D (and A D) systems in polar solvents could be generated through a route other than direct formation from the primary excited singlet state 1A* -f- D-*- 1(A D+'). The free enthalpy gained in the exciplex dissociation i to yield the solvated radical ion pair is typically of the order of 0.2 eV in polar solvents and there was no reason to assume the reverse reaction, ^A~ + 2D+ - - 1(A-D'1-) to proceed with a sizeable rate. In spite of the weak exciplex fluorescence on the unlinked pyrene/N,N-diethylaniline system in the polar solvent isopropanol Petrov et al. [11] detected a magnetic field effect ofO 6% and interpreted it in terms of the magnetic field sensitivity of the singlet triplet con- version of the radical ion pair- Recently further inves- tigations on the same system in methanol have been reported [13]. It was the aim of the present work to study the exciplex formation reaction K^-CCH;.),,-^)-^ KA-CCHa^D^ (2) (rip) (ecc) of polymethylene-linked A D systems in acetonitrile because it was expected that the absence of the com- plete separation of the radicals would enhance the ex- ciplex yield, in addition to the Coulombic-field-assisted diffusion, a process which we have called "harpooning" and which has been observed in energetically more favourable systems [7,12]. 2. Experimental The investigated compounds,A (CH^)^ D,withA = pyrene, D = N,N-dimethylaniline and n = 8 16 (abbreviated A(n)D) were synthesized Their purity was checked by IR and NMR spectroscopy. The com- pounds finally used for sample preparation were HPLC selected. Acetonitrile (C ^CN) was dried by distilla- tion over P40]n and transferred to the sample cuvette under nitrogen. All samples were degassed by five or six freeze pump thaw cycles. It turned out be vital to start the sample preparation in complete darkness with predegassed solvent, in order to avoid photo- chemically induced defects on the compounds, such as broken polymethylene chains, which would lead to erroneous results. Fluorescence spectra were measured on commercial instruments: a Spex (Fluorolog) and a calibrated Hitachi/Perkin Elmer fluoroscope; the latter with the possibility of temperature variation. The instrumental requirements to measure the magnetic field dependence of the relative exciplex fluorescence intensity were easy to fulfil- In a photo- stationary experiment (similar to r f. [11]) UV light selected with an interference filter (337 run) from a high-pressure xenon arc continuously excited the sample placed between the pole pieces of an electro- magnet (Bruker type B-E10). A photomultipher (Valvo XP 2230) received the exciplex fluorescence through an interference filter (595 run) plus a Schott filter (GG 495) and a 1.5 m long fiber glass light cable. Thus, any magnetic field interference with the photo- electrons in the photomultiplier is totally excluded. The output signal was large enough to drive anXY recorder while the magnetic field was swept from 0 to 1000 G- No further method to improve the S/N ratio was applied. Fluorescence decay times were measured with (i) the single-photon counting method, (ii) an apparatus with N^-Iaser excitation, fast photomulti- plier and fast oscilloscope. The fluorescence nsetime has been studied with a picosecond streak camera (Hamamatsu) after excitation of the sample with a picosecond pulse from a Nd/YAG laser [7,12,14]. In 20 Volume 118, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 12 July 1985 continuation of our practice the parameter J (in G) (l G = 0.1 mT), which is the magnetic induction or the magnetic flux "density measured with a Gaussmeter (Bell 620), is used to specify the magnetic field strength applied at the sample. 3. Results and discussion The fluorescence spectrum of a 10~4 M solution ofA(16)D in acetonitrile obtained after excitation at 337 nm is shown in fig. 1. Spectrum (1) exhibits the strongly quenched fluorescence of the pyrene part with maxima at 378, 398, 417 and 464 nm. The struc- tureless exciplex fluorescence appears to the red at 580 nm (17200 cm-1). A magnetic Held offi = 350 G was found to increase the exciplex fluorescence dra- matically (spectrum (2)) but left the pyrene fluores- cence practically unaltered. The saturation intensity of the exciplex fluorescence at B = 700 G is about 47% higher than at 0 G. The effect is independent of the intensity and the wavelength of the exciting light- The time dependence of the exciplex fluorescence at 557 nm after pulse excitation (337 nm, 2.5 ns half- width) is shown in fig. 2 for B = 0 (curve 1) and B = 500 600 IU- .< 8- ' < 'w^ i i? 6- . Single-photOD-counting histograms showing exciplex fluorescence decay ofPy(16)DMA in CHsCN at 557 lun (1) without (TI = 22 its), (2) with external magnetic field of B = 350 G (Ta = 31 ns). 184 ns/50 channels. 350 G (curve 2). A comparison of both curves shows that curve 2 is only slightly higher m amplitude at the beginning of the decay. The two curves, however, differ in their decay times measured at the wavelength of the exciplex maximum and at 526, 557, 595 and 614 nm. The initial decay time (1/e) is about 22 ns for curve 1 and about 31 ns for curve 2. At longer times both curves level off from purely single expo- nential behaviour. However, it is important to recognize that the measured exciplex decay times are almost identical with the decay times T^(B = 0) = 22 ns and Ty(B = 500 G) = 32 ns of the radical ion pair as ob- tained from time resolved absorption experiments [10]. In a picosecond experiment (for experimental details see refs. [12,14]) the riseiime of the exciplex fluorescence time function has been examined in order to determine that part of the exciplex signal which could have possibly been generated from pre- formed complexes. Le. configurations in which A and D are in close contact at the instant of absorption- The picosecond excitation pulse at 354 nm had a halfwidth. of 28 ps. T-he streak camera signal which monitored the exciplex emission in the wavelength range 580 670 nm showed no fast component- The time function followed essentially the difference of two exponentials: exp( f/22 ns) exp( r/2.1 ns), the 2.1 ns being the decay time of the quenched pyrene fluorescence during which the radical pair is built up., On the basis of all the experimental facts available 21 Volume 118, number l CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 12 July 1985 ' (n)1 D "(npl Si2 - 2l-:\ ^ll8) 1i2,- 2r-fl ^ ^ (Aini D) == = (A (n) D ) ^ 'k., i <ls IB) ; krt ^(niT) lkr' Scheme I so far the general reaction scheme I was constructed Besides direct exciplex formation from the locally excited singlet state (Age), indirect exciplex forma- tion via the singlet radical ion pair, ^rip), is considered It occurs in a two-step process, formation of the ^rip) by photoinduced electron transfer from the donor D to the excited acceptor ^A*, followed by the associa- tion to the exciplex (k^c). The latter reaction step competes with the recombination of the ^rip) to the ground state designated by the rate constant fc and "with the hyperf ne-mduced conversion to the triplet radical ion pair, ^rip), designated by the magnetic field dependent rate constant k^( ). This singlet trip- let conversion is affected by an external magnetic eld as described above and is used here to perturb several reaction rates in scheme I in order to show that m compounds A(n)D m a polar solvent exciplexes are predominantly generated from the singlet radical ion pair. Particularly instructive findings supporting this view and providing B in and saturation values have been obtained with the photostationary magnetic field experiment depicted in fig- 3. The magnetic field dependence of the relative exciplex fluorescence in- tensity Q'(B) = I'(B)II'CG) of a series of similar com- pounds A-(CH2)n-D with n = 8 16 has been recorded at 595 nm. From the set of data we first select compound A(16)D which upon application of a continuously varying external magnetic field shows a monotonously rising fluorescence intensity. The relative intensity at saturation is u'( ) = 1.47. A -^n value of 135 G which is the same as that obtained from triplet extinction measurements [8,10] can be evaluated. On the basis of reaction scheme I, with the ex- perimentally justified assumption k^ ^ k^, and ignor- ing the direct exciplex formation channel (fc ), the 0 200 WO 600 800 1000 Magnetic Field Strength B / Gauss Fig- 3. Magnetic field dependence of the relative exciplex fluorescence intensity Q' = f( )fl'(0) of compounds Py(CH2)nDMA,n = 8-16, m CHaCN, detected at 595 nni and at room temperature. exciplex quantum efficiency for polar solvents can be written as ^' = PST 'PK f' ' which is the product of the individual efficiencies: ^rip) formation, ipg, exciplex formation from the ^rip), ip^, and exciplex emission, ip'. This leads in detail to k- k. ^ ^ =k+ I/T ic+fc+k fR) k T0 ' ^sr ^'O "ie "ig -stY"^ (3) with k- k- ^^r'o ^TO TO is the lifetime ofunquenched 1A* C'H3 in a polar solvent (here acetonitrile), T'Q is the exciplex lifetime in the absence of the dissociation process, k^, which dominates the exciplex decay (k^ ^> l/Tg). The ratio of the exciplex signals at any magnetic field strength then becomes ^^ ^ 0'Q?) ^ I'(B) ^ ze + ^ + fcst(0) ^ r'(B) ^ 0'(0) /'(0) K^+k^+k^W T'(O)' 22 Volume 118, number I CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 12 July 1985 where the identity T' = T^ is assumed. For A(16)D at B = 350 G, Q' = l 42 0.02 is obtained from the photostationary 'experiment (cf- fig. 3, n = 16). Life- time measurements (cf fig. 2) yield for T'(350)/r (0) = 1.41, which is in excellent agreement and satisfies ea- (4)- We may therefore conclude that with the com- pound A(16)D in acetonitrile the singlet radical ion pair, ^rip), is the precursor of the emitting exciplex. A similarly good agreement has been found for other compounds e.g. A(11)D where '(350) = L25 and T'C350)/T'(0) = 23-5 ns/19 ns = 1.24. On the basis of scheme I we can easily calculate the magnetic field dependent triplet yield ratio: Combining eqs. (4) and (5) leads to the relation 6(fl) k^(B) Q\B^~k,fO)- (5) (6) For A(16)D m C^CN at saturation, with (") = 0.65 from absorption measurements [10] and '( ) = 1.47 from exciplex emission measurements k.^00)! k^(0) = 0.44 is obtained. In order to assess the energy difference (A ") between the exciplex and the radical ion pair, we per- formed temperature variation experiments. Substitut- ing in eq. (3) foiky + I/T-Q = kf/<f> with ij> the quantum efficiency of the ^A^'O 6)D fluorescence and k f its radiative rate constant eq (3) can be rewritten. As according to r f. [9] in acetonitrile k^^k^ one ob- tains k s k re (7) If one assumes that the ratios in eq. (7), except k^Jk^, aie temperature independent, one can write (070)0/7') = const. expC AE'/fcT) - (8) From the temperature dependence of<f>'fif> in the temperature range 290 3 40 K the energy difference Af = 0.13 eV is calculated. AU experimental results and the above analysis are consistent with the assumption that the rate constants, k^ and k^, for the intramolecular association and dissociation of the exciplex are in the 109 s~1 range or faster. We now return to fig- 3 where the magnetic field dependence of the relative exciplex signals is plotted for compounds with different lengths of the CH^ chain. The exciplex fluorescence intensities at zero magnetic field decrease with decreasing chain length (from n = 16 to 8 as 1.0, 1.0, 0.86, 0.74, 0.65, 0.5, 0.25). We recognize that the magnetic field effect on the exciplex emission, Q', also decreases with decreas- ing chain length while the characteristic B-^n value in- creases. The exciplex signals which exhibit a positive magnetic field effect have the inverse behaviour of the triplet signals described recently [7,8,10]. This pertains also to the signals obtained from the com- pounds with medium chain length, n = 8 1 i, where pronounced minima (which correspond to maxima in the triplet signals) appear which shift to higher mag- netic field strengths as the length of the aliphatic chains between the chromophores is reduced. As pointed out earlier, this has to do with the increasing influence of the exchange interaction, 2J, in the radical ion pair which impedes the hyperfine interac- tion- The appearance of minima in the magnetic field curves is an indication of the degeneracy of S and T_ states where additional hyperfine-coupling-induced singlet triplet mixing will occur when the relation 2/ = g B is satisfied. However, the position of the mini- ma need not correspond to the maxima of the pair- distribution functions (most probable end end dis- tance of radical pairs) as has been shown theoretically by a stochastic Liouville method, in which the dynam- ics of the polymethylene chains was incorporated in a biradical CIDNP model [151. A similar calculation has been perfonned [16] based on a formulation in terms of a density matrix equation of motion taking into account both the spin dynamics and the chain folding. TJie agreement of the calculations with the experimental data again points to the important con- tribution of the folding dynamics to the observed magnetic field dependence. The results of the study described m this contibu- tion indicate that the method ofmagneto-optically detected spin conversion (MODSC) spectroscopy may serve as a new tool for the investigation of polymer dynamics, particularly by applying a pair of chiomo- phore labels with suitable A/D properties, which in a photoinduced reaction in polar media lead to radical 23 Volume 118, number I CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 12 July 1985 ion pairs and exciplexes MODSC spectroscopy has many advantages over C DNP spectioscopy. It can be combined with time-reso ved methods down to the nanosecond range, its sensitivity can be raised by modulating the excitation light or the magnetic field, and, last not least, it requires relatively little effort to set up the necessary instrumentation. A summary of MODSC spectroscopy methods will appear elsewhere [17]. Acknowledgement H. Meyer provided competent technical assistance. He also developed the magnetic-field-modulation technique which we used m the early stage of this work. B. Frederichs prepared the samples and carried out the single-photon-counting experiments. R. Mitzkus and J. Ihlemann assisted in the picosecond experiment. head.ce:title: Magnetic field dependence of intramolecular exciplex formation in polymethyelene-linked A–D systems

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Max-Planck-Institut für Biophysikalische Chemie, Abteilung Spektroskopie, D-3400 Göttingen, Federal Republic of Germany

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: An extremely large increase of exciplex fluorescence intensity has been observed with photoexcited compounds pyrene-(CH2) n - DMA in acetonitrile when an external magnetic field of several hundred gauss is applied. The effect is readily explained as originating from the radical ion pair which can undergo a magnetic-field-dependent singlet-triplet conversion due to nuclear hyperfine coupling, or an association to form the exciplex. The increasing influence of the exchange interaction in the radical ion pair with decreasing chain length (CH2) n is evident.
